posts.name: Ambrish
posts.cooked:
Hello,

We have an ARM which extends beyond chassis when it is laying down. Is there a programmable way to achieve this in Robot Init time ? Right now we can only lift it up once Teleop is enabled with some feed forward.

Thank you for your inputs!

-Ambrish

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: Can you turn brake mode on on the motors? Can you put a mechanical stop in that you can remove? Can you balance it?

posts.name: Ambrish
posts.cooked:
When we just power on the Robot, my understanding is that all motors are disabled. So not sure how to put it in brake mode.

Any leads/pointers for it ?

Thanks!

posts.name: Emre
posts.cooked: What motors are you using? You can do via app or in code.

posts.name: Patrick Woolfenden
posts.cooked:
ambrish3281:

We have an ARM which extends beyond chassis when it is laying down.

We have this same issue. To be within frame perimeter, we secure the arm up with a kickstand that spring loads out of the way once the arm moves when the robot is enabled.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: I’ve seen teams just use masking/painter’s tape to hold something until the first time the motors move it and break the tape.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
I’d done fishing line and well-tied rubber bands before, but never painter tape.  Filing that one away.

The other thing I haven’t seen mentioned: a numerically higher gear ratio usually creates more friction in the system.  At a suitably high ratio and with brake mode enabled on the motor controllers (how to do that varies by controller), even a fairly hefty arm can stay up.  I don’t recall how much ours weighs all-in, but two NEOs at around 240:1 total reduction did the trick.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.custom_user_title: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: For some smaller deadaxle arms, the snowblower hex motors with a single sprocket reduction like 16T to 48T in brake mode will hold the arm upright vertically, not sure about at 45° or a more difficult angle without active motor power and closed loop control.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: As a very similar idea: I have used a tab of Velcro many times to hold an intake or other component in, this year included.

posts.name: Ambrish
posts.cooked:
Thanks everyone for the info! Really appreciate it. We will try out suggestions and see which one works for us.

Thanks! -Ambrish

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: You can set motors to brake even when the robot is in disabled mode.
